div.pre: 1826 Khisht Tepe on the Oxus River, province of Qunduz, c. 110 km. E of Balkh (anc. Bactra, Bactriana), 1946 Burial: after 140 B.C. (Fussman); c. 100 B.C. (Bivar) Contents: 627+ AR Alexander III: 1 plated tetradr. (unc. mint) Antiochus II: 4 tetradr. (Bactra with por- trait of Diodotus) Antiochus Hierax: 1 tetradr. (Ilium) Alexander I Bala: 1 tetradr. (Seleuceia ad Tigrim) Diodotus, Bactria: 1 tetradr. Euthydemus I: 12 tetradr. Demetrius I: 8 tetradr. Euthydemus II: 5 tetradr. Agathocles: 3 tetradr. Antimachus Theos: 14 tetradr. Demetrius II: 50 tetradr. Eucratides I: 147 tetradr. (3 with rev. Heliocles and Laodice) Eucratides I or II: 130 tetradr. (rev. Apollo) Plato: 12 tetradr. Heliocles I: 204 tetradr.; 17 dr. Lysias: 4 tetradr. Theophilus: 1 tetradr. Antialcidas: 3 tetradr. Amyntas: 5 double-decadr. Archebius: 2 tetradr. Philoxenus: 1 tetradr. Hermaeus: 1 tetradr. Disposition: Cabul 627 Bivar, NNM India 3 (1955), illus. (= JNSI 1955, pp. 37-52) Curiel-Fussman, Le trésor monétaire de Qunduz (Paris, 1965), illus. Several coins appearing in commerce during the 1950's and 1960's seem to derive from this hd., which may have been considerably larger than originally assumed. The distinctions between homonymous kings in the list above are disputed in some cases. Especially the existence of two king Eucratides may be doubted
